application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Combined statistical model of bone shape and mechanical properties
Bonaretti S., Helgason B., Seiler C., Reyes M., Büchler P. ISTB, University of Bern, Switzerland
Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering 24-27 February 2010, Valencia
How can we model bone variability?
> State of the art of bone mechanical studies: — Based on patient-specific
models — Limited number of bones — Variability included in
> To model bone shape variability > To evaluate bone mechanical behavior > Population-based study:
> Initial application about femurs — Stiffness comparison between genders
Segmented Rigid and non-rigid Shape New CT images registration Model instances
Volume Material BC mesh properties propagation
> Identification and delineation of structures in images:
> Process of aligning images so that corresponding features can be extracted — Correspondences: establishment of which point on one
image corresponds to the same anatomical point in the other
Hajnal J.V. et al. Medical Image Registration. Biomedical Engineering Series. 2001. 6

Thirion J.-P. Image matching as a diffusion process: an analogy whit Maxwell’s demons. Medical Image analysis, 2(3), 243-260, 1996. Vercauteren T. et al. Symmetric log-domain diffeomorphic registration: a demons-based approach. MICCAI 2008.
> Correspondences allow us to calculate images covariance matrix
matrix (eigenvector (eigenvalues (eigenvector matrix) matrix) matrix)T Shape Model — Eigenvectors: direction of variation
— Eigenvalues: amount of variation along the correspondent direction 75% 15% 10%
Cootes T.F. et al. Active shape models – their training and application. Computer vision and image understanding, 61(1), 38-59, 1995.
> They are created along eigenvector directions and for variations defined by the eigenvalues:
Paulsen R.R. et al. Markov Random Field Surface Reconstruction. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics. 99, 2009. Schöberl J. at al. http://www.hpfem.jku.at/netgen/
CT intensities ρQCT ρash ρapp E
Image ρ 1.49 3Ash = (ρQCT+0.09)/1.14 ρash/ρapp=0.60 E(GPa)=6.850 r a p p (g/cm ) calibration: ESP - EFP

Schileo E. et al. An accurate estimation of bone density improves the accuracy of subject-specific finite element methods. Journal of Biomechanics, 2008, 41, 2483-2491. Helgason B. et al. Mathematical relationship between bone density and mechanical properties: a literature review. Clinical Biomechanics, 2008, 23, 135-146
> Load application points and boundary conditions can be propagated using calculated DVFs
Application on the femur Statistical model
> CT images — 80 for females — 57 for males
> Statistical Shape Model: — Use of the first 4 modes
(77% of variation for females, 83% for males) — Generation of 40 instances for each gender
Application on the femur Mechanical simulation
> 10-node tetrahedral mesh > L = 800N, head-intercondyle direction > Distal part encastred
> Same mineral content in all instances
> Conclusion — We proposed a method to model bone variability — Finite element are used to evaluate bone mechanical behavior — Semi-automatic pipeline
> Future work — Shape model validation — Statistical model that includes both shape and intensities — Mechanical simulation of physiological situations
